pros: great support staff, excellent resources to expedite life saving care

pros:
- many locations that you can transfer to (athens, fayette, newnan, atlanta, henry, etc.) 
- they have outpatient options for you if you need a break from bedside. 
- They offer 4 - 10 hours shifts, 3 - 12 hours shifts, or 5 - 8 hours shifts.
- EPEP program that will allow Pre-PA students and Pre-med students the ability to shadow under different providers.
cons:
- not great pay; they will keep your pay low if you transfer internally to new roles. 
- if you go from a full time position to a PRN position they will keep your pay rate the same despite taking away benefits. 
- their benefits package isn't great and somewhat restrictive. You must stay within Piedmont and their providers if you use their insurance. The copay/premiums are also very high for you to be staying within their provider system. 
- Very lack luster management - not interested in their employees, tend to stir the pot by adding drama to the unit, friends with HR/directors so can be hard to voice a complaint, side with doctors/physicians over nurses/nurse practitioners,
- Don't invest in the growth of their employees - current employees cannot participate in the EPEP program for shadowing opportunities under different providers/physicians. Only Pre-PA/Pre-Med students are allowed. CMAs looking to become RN's, RN's looking to become NP's will not be able to access Piedmont's EPEP program. That is very disappointing as this could be a great way to retain great employees who know your health system and know the patients. 
- Last minute floats to different locations. Not much heads up (same day notification that you are being floated to a different location. Example, you are staffed in Douglasville and are asked to float to Ellijay for the day at 0630 am and you need to be there by 0800 am). If you are PRN they do not reimburse mileage.

review_title: Better before the current CEO came
pros: Coworkers and rapport, generally reasonable expectations regarding work to be done.  Overall atmosphere of contentment among most departments.  Piedmont has a great medical staff, making it a place to be proud to say you work there.
cons: I've been there a LONG time.  Communication from management to staff who are expected to do the job is terrible.  I've learned over time this is not just within my department, but across many departments to the point we joke it is a Piedmont philosophy (to not communicate changes).  It's almost as if nobody wants to inform staff because they might change their mind, and it creates a situation where people within the departments may be doing things all sorts of different ways because of lack of direction.

review_title: A previously well-respected hospital now being run by money-hungry businessmen hiding under promises of patient safety.
pros: History of patient care at Piedmont Hospital goes back over a century; since the founding times, generations of physicians, nurses and support staff worked hard to turn Piedmont Hospital into the top private medical center in Atlanta,  where patients would be seen by the best doctors in their specialties, and received the best care whether they are treated in the clinic or in the hospital.
cons: Things changed when the new Piedmont Healthcare top leadership (under Tim Stack) decided that the best way to load up their big wallets is getting more revenue (more patients to pay), which means buying more hospitals and physician practices.  While they say that the integration process brings more choices to patients, in fact, the opposite is true. These patients are now locked into the same system, if they want to keep their doctors. There's a reason whenever something like this happens, it has to be cleared by the anti-trust laws. Another little-known secret to getting more revenue is to coach the surgeons and physicians to come up with (not-so-honest) documentation that would justifies the highest insurance reimbursement.

review_title: I enjoy working at piedmont because the job is very interesting and I feel like I directly influence the quality of care
job_title: Great Place to Work and Grow In Your Career in Atlanta, GA
pros:
- Interesting work
- Career growth and training offered
- Supportive management in most cases
- Good work life balance
- Reasonable pay and it's nice to get a small bonus at the end of the year
cons:
- PTO policy is not that good and misleading when you are hired
- Not many "extra" benefits
- Medical benefits are not that great for this to be a hospital.  You would think they would be better.
- Too many old timers in IT have too much control.  It gets to the point where you cant do you job efficienty because of all the restrictions IT has in place.

pros:
-ER doctors are nice
-flexible scheduling
cons:
ER charge nurses need to be realistic in their expectations of turn over rates for patients and staffing. 
Unprofessional nurses, who work in the back of Piedmont Atlanta ED "Holding zone, transition unit" who constantly complain about not wanting to take patients. They constantly complain about "psych patients' or "this patient is crazy, that patient is crazy." They constantly give push back from us ER nurses, who attempt to give them report to take new patients. What is the point in having "holding zone, transition unit" for patients needing beds on the medical floor, if the nurses refuse to take them. you might as well close that unit down! They complain about "we can't take that patient because they're on contact precautions, or they're not walky talky, or they can't use the bathroom on their own." You can't pick and choose all your patients. 3-4 admissions at the same time is not too much to ask, if the ER red zone is full, especially given there are at least 3 nurses that work back there, which is a small case load.
-POOR STAFFING. put the ER on diversion when staffing ratio becomes unsafe. This patients your hospital at risk, the patient at risk, and the doctors at risk for liability.

job_title: Procedure Support Technician in Atlanta, GA
pros: Thank You For The Opportunity
cons: Hard To Promote Within The Company

job_title: RN Charge Nurse in Atlanta, GA
pros: LOVE the people I work with. It is like a family here.
cons: Management doesn't get it. I think they try to make it look like they want to understand with engagement surveys and forums, but when they keep pushing business stuff over simple front-line compassionate care, it really sucks! If we could just do our job with adequate staffing, the patient surveys would speak for themselves. When we are forced to do more than we are able to in the time allowed, patients suffer and so does their productivity and numbers. It seems that a majority of department managers and directors are hand-picked and the panel interviewing process is just for show. They don't listen to the front line staff about whether we want the person or not.

review_title: The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly
job_title: Patient Care Technician in Atlanta, GA
pros: Close to home, benefits, friendship
cons: All this that I am stating is from my day yo day work experience. We’re always short-staffed. It can be 2 techs to start the day and they both can end up with 15+ patients by the end of the day. (true statement). The upper management isn’t listening to our complaints. It’s not safe for the staff and especially not the patients. Our scores are low because we’re understaffed and overworked. Staff is either quitting or calling out because who wants to go to work everyday and be yet again understaff. Let me not forget the teamwork. Yes we have teamwork with some staff but then you have some that completely will have that’s not my job mentality. Then guess what happens, someone ends up hurt because you didn’t answer that call light or bed alarm. Also transport is always short staffed as well. So guess whose taking the patients out for discharge. You guessed it, either the nurses or the techs. Let me not forget, the patient is always right.

review_title: Piedmont has been by far the fairest and most caring place to work for in my career, it's like home.
pros: I've never worked anywhere that went above and beyond the norm to provide such fair and equitable treatment of their staff compared to what I've experienced at Piedmont Healthcare.  I honestly feel that an enormous amount of time, work and expense has gone into rewards programs for all levels of employees, with support from the highest levels of  leadership.  Strategies that impact employees as well as patient care are not taken lightly  or without extreme diligence, our patient's care and needs have always been first and  foremost.  I have received excellent care at Piedmont when I've needed it, and so have my family members.
cons: There are always challenges when you are in growth-mode, but expansion is much better than the alternative, and necessary to survive in this ever-changing industry.  I wouldn't care to work for a system that is satisfied with status-quo, or worse, declining.

pros: Has Epic as EMR, friendly day to day staff
cons: As a doctor, turnover is incredibly high across the 5-6 Piedmont hospitals. Main manager expects you to be available to work at ALL the hospitals if needed, which is frequent given high turnover/large amount open shifts. Management of patients is dictated by Corporate whose main focus seems to be money; using templates and computer protocols over actual care/safety of patients.  Pay is poor compared to avg compensation esp in the Southeast. They explain base is less bc it's compensated for by bonuses.. The bonus structure is unrealistic as example-  no bonus this year...Scheduling is created by a non medical person at Piedmont headquarters and is posted online for all the hospitals- changes all the time with no alerts, which has resulted in docs not showing up for shifts. Management is very malignant, witnessed many great clinical docs at several Piedmont hospitals harassed until they quit if they were too vocal.

review_title: Patient Access Associate Emergency Dept (Newnan, Ga).
job_title: Patient Access Associate ER in Newnan, GA
pros: Experienced, compassionate, hard working team members. Piedmont offer competitive pay. Beautiful facility with all the bells and whistles.  Patient care is number one because of the federal money (Medicare, Medicaid, and Affordable Care Act dollars that it takes to keep the doors open.  Mission statement begins with "First do no harm"
cons: Leadership does not follow its own mission state with regards to employees.  First of all leadership has no accountability.  There is no grievence  policy in place for employees. Leadership rules. I tried to reach out to Human Resources and my manager's director and no one would allow me to litigate my grievance.  I was documented for calling out sick with a doctor's excuse, from a Piedmont Healthcare urgent care affiliate, for the stomach flu, which is contagious, while my duties were to register patients at bedside for emergency dept care. I have been harmed. Subsequently, I was terminated.  My story to be continued in the courts.

review_title: Excellent hospital drifting down hill rapidly
pros:
Excellent subspecialists in many areas
Nurses generally very good but (not enough of them)
Facilities generally good
cons:
Management is focused on making money, not patient care and not employee satisfaction
Nurses are not respected and are leaving the hospital for better work environments
Decisions to buy cardiology practices (Piedmont Heart Institute) has resulted in wasteful care, less continuity of care, and in general, poorer care. 
IMS hospitalist service is of uneven quality and continuity of care is poor
ER MDs are  worse than ever
No expertise on staff in quality assurance and no statistical expertise available on staff.

pros: There are none in my opinion. Not if your at the bottom of the totem pole.
cons: Productivity and quality standards are not fair. They are inconsistent. We have 5011 processes and 7000 of them are broken, you do the Math. You can't move up. You can barely make a lateral move. Management has a tendency of blocking their employees if they can't take the hit.

job_title: Care Manager (Case Manager) in Fayetteville, GA

If we don't leave the building, the 30 minute lunch break is automatically deducted.  Medical insurance employee premiums seem to be a bit higher than other area healthcare employers.

Many conversations with manager and director fell on deaf ears. Concerns had to be escalated to Chief nurse officer before they were addressed.  High deductibles for surgery and procedures. Once you think your done paying off your bill, you will get another $600.00 provider bill not reimbursed by insurance.

review_title: Several Years of Experience - Avoid Piedmont if you can
pros:
When I first started here, it was a great place to work, had an understanding manager who offered development and encouraged growth and learning.  This all changed after new managment was brought in to implement the EMR.

Benefits were good initially, but once the healthcare initiative took effect, the healthcare plan changed.

Co-workers on a non-management level were friendly, and most worked well together.
cons:
When new management took effect a couple years ago, things changed.  The management in the IT department proved to incompetent.  Offering no professional development, nor guidance to further employee's careers.  At times, it was a hostile work environment and the threat of retaliation was high.  

Managers that underperformed constantly were covered by their leadership, even though the team knew and expressed concern.  They seem to promote the bad managers, while keeping the good ones "in place".  

There is no room for professional advancement opportunities, and some of the ways interviews are handled are worthy of HR complaints.

Lack of recognition for employees that perform above the standard set.

New health benefit is lacking in taking care of the employee, but appears to be more of a financial decision.

Will Order Immediate Termination or Documented Corrective Action for any Ongoing Documented Concerns regarding Interoffice Conflict or Concerns regarding the Piedmont Healthcare System.  No Open Door Policy Advisement Management or Conflict Resolution for Employee / Physician Concerns.

pros: Great family atmosphere. You work with doctors, nurses and consult docs all the time. They are usually great to be around.

job_title: Interventional Radiology Technologist in Atlanta, GA
pros: Competitive pay. Great people and teamwork. Fully respected by peers, management, and MDs working with daily.  The company has changed a lot in the past five years for the better. They are really refocusing on creating an environment of safety for the patient and fostering relationships with employees. The Interventional team is a particularly gifted team that helped me grow and reach my full potential within the role. If it weren't for all of them I wouldn't be the Technologist I am today.
cons: Can be long hours due to high patient volume, but this is expected any time you are taking on a role that involves taking call.

pros:
Some of the reasons that love working here are that we have a beautiful newer building, competitive pay from what I have seen, and in my experience our leadership seems to actually care about us. 
With our health insurance if you use a "Tier 1" doctor its cheap! I haven't had any major medical issues but I haven't encountered any unexpected bills.
401k matching of 6% (and there are rumors of possibly increasing to 7%)
cons: Small hospital, but growing quickly! They are also building a new exit/entrance ramp to interstate 85 right next to our hospital so that probably means we will grow even faster after that opens.

review_title: Not a good place for Advanced Practice Providers (PA
job_title: Advanced Practice Provider (PA/NP) in Atlanta, GA
pros: Large healthcare system with challenging patients and situations.  Given high turnover (which is bad) there are many areas for movement if you don't like your current area (good)
cons:
Very poor treatment of PA/NP's overall it's like stepping back 20 years.  Upper level management is grossly out of touch with the role of the PA/NP at present in the healthcare system. You cannot change code status, we were only recently allowed to pronounce death.  You cannot park in "physician" parking like you can at many of the other healthcare systems around town.  You are unable to enter the doctors lounge as a provider because you are not a physician, something extended to PA/NP's at other Atlanta area facilities.  You are unable to gain access to the doctors dining room again another perk allotted to you at other atlanta area facilities.  There is no APP council to allow for your voice to be heard.  The term "Physician Extender" or "Midlevel" are still thrown around like they are the accepted terms for our profession.  

Benefits are mostly ok, the health benefits are a bit harsh, with in network deductible being $1500 and out of network deductible being $20,000 yes you read that correctly.  

CME reimbursement is very low @ $1500 for PA/NP's but MD's get $6000 yearly. Even Emory pays higher @ $2000 to their PA/NP's.  

Hourly overtime/extra pay is abysmally low @ $50/hr where you may be the only provider watching 100+ patients!

It's a bit of a tattle tale environment.  Managers tell you to "variance" other employees for even small infractions. Everyone on edge wondering when the next time they are going to tick someone off who will then go to HR or their manager.  There is very little being an adult and working things out on your own.  It feels more like you work to not get in trouble than to help get folks better.

pros: Management treats you like an adult and allows your work to speak for itself. Professional environment and I like and respect the people that I work with. This is definitely a place that I can see myself retiring from
cons: Building is a little dated and having IT issues can sometimes cripple your productivity. They are extremely nice but when you have deadlines to meet it can cause undue stress.

review_title: Revenue Cycle Leader (Physician Billing) - Proceed with Caution!
job_title: Revenue Cycle Coding and Analytics Manager in Atlanta, GA
pros:
Piedmont uses Epic for both EMR and Revenue Cycle and Tableau for data analysis, report creation, and dashboarding.

Piedmont has an in-house training program for Quality Process Improvement, selected employees can achieve Six Sigma certification upon completion of the program.

Healthy Savings Account - You can earn dollars to spend on healthcare by performing healthy activities, i.e. physical, fitbit steps per month, health coaching, etc. This is to a maximum based on enrollment, single or family.
cons:
Deceptive Hiring Practices - Request a copy of the job description for which you are being considered. Clarify if staffing resources are budgeted/approved or pending/not approved. Request history of how the position came to be as well as the functional team(s) for which you are responsible. For my role, Revenue Cycle Coding and Analytics Manager, I was not provided an accurate job description to price the role during the offer/acceptance process. I was also told that I would have a Supervisor to support my teams, however, this was not approved for posting for over 6 months. I also learned after I began working that my role was actually a consolidated role (formerly belonging to 2 people for multiple teams) although the job description was not adjusted to reflect consolidated teams and responsibilities.

Outsourced A/R - Inquire about the business case to utilize external vendors and consultants for A/R management and other revenue cycle support services and if/when the work will return in house? On the Physician Billing side, the A/R collections are divided between onsite Piedmont employees and an external vendor. Piedmont has also engaged an external consulting practice for "assistance" with a number of the revenue cycle functions across both Physician Billing, Hospital Billing, and Single Billing office. 

Leadership Turnover – Inquire about front line leader turnover and plans to address based on lessons learned. In the 8 months that I spent in Piedmont's Revenue Cycle for Physician Billing, they experienced the following turnover: 1 Coding Manager, 2 Coding Supervisors, 1 Collections/Follow-Up Manager, 1 Collections/Follow-Up Supervisor, as well as my position - Revenue Cycle Coding and Analytics Manager. 

Health Insurance - Piedmont has their own health plan which Cigna administers. You will pay more out of pocket to access non-Piedmont physicians or Hospitals outside of wellness benefits; i.e. physical or mammogram, etc.

401K - Piedmont will not match until you've had a full year of service.

review_title: Not the best place to work...
pros:
PTO Policy revisions now allow us to carry over a PTO balance based on a cap rather than losing the balance.

Explanation for my ratings:

- Career Opportunities:  Piedmont typically hires management from outside and does not develop people internally.

- Compensation & Benefits
Very poor health insurance (we'd be better off on Obama-Care)

- Senior Management
The general opinion of the C-Level Execs (CEO, etc..) is that they do not care about the employees.  Just achieving metrics to justify their bonuses.  Employees are a means to achieving this end. 

- Culture and Values
The published culture and values are very nice, but not typically followed.  It's more "public relations".
cons:
Health Insurance:
Designed to drive employees to using Piedmont.  The downside is that Piedmont Physicians do not have practices in all areas where employees live resulting in employees either having to drive many miles to an in-network doctor or force you to go out-of-network.

Prescription Insurance
Required to use Express-Scripts for recurring prescriptions.  If for some reason Express-Scripts does not send you the medication on time and  you need to get it provided through a pharmacy, they will require you to pay the copay for a monthly supply and authorize the pharmacy to provide you with a 14 day supply. 

Advancement Opportunities:
Very little chance to advance your career at Piedmont.  In many cases management is hired from outside rather than promoting from within the company.  If promotions from within the company do occur, it is more often based on the good-ole-boy system (friends, favors, etc...) which results in many people in management with no leadership ability (and with the lack of any internal training, new managers who have never managed before are ill-prepared to tackle this role leaving the employees very disgruntled since the new manager does not know what they are doing). 

Human Resources
HR does not investigate issues and concerns brought about by employees but rather chat with the manager to get their opinion and use that as the conclusion.  The lack of any impartiality from HR results in the employee base not trusting HR.  Secondly, HR does not evaluate whether new applicants meet the minimum qualifications for the job.  If the person was referred by someone high up in the company, they are rubber stamped and fast-tracked into the position.  This results in the team having to make up for the lack of an effective team-mate.

pros: You get a paycheck. Weekend and night shift bonuses.
cons:
Very very hostile work environment. Management cares nothing about the technicians and have no interpersonal skills. They're very mean and don't know how to talk or manage people so communication is always lost. Technician satisfaction is extremely low therefore there's also an extremely high turnover rate to the point HR had to come in and have meetings to see what was going on. Constantly new technicians being trained by other new technicians because everyone quits once they realize what really goes on in the pharmacy. 

Refuse to cross-train so there's no room for growth. If you start with doing floor runs it may take you years or you'll maybe never get into the IV room or OR satellite. Management moves up and trains people in different areas depending on if they like you personally or not. For example,  pharmacy students work here NONE of them have ever been trained in the IV room or OR satellite they only do runs, and they've been here for years. Another downfall of refusing to cross-train coupled with high turnover is there's constantly holes in the schedule putting more workload on other techs. If everyone was cross-trained anybody could pick up those shifts making it easier for everyone. I've never worked at a hospital where everybody wasn't able to do everything, it just hurts the department in the end. 

 The workload is extremely heavy. Management sets unrealistic goals and rules, that they themselves don't abide by (no talking, no cellphones). They will overwork you and ask you to work plenty of overtime shifts but when you ask them for an accommodation in scheduling or anything else you're met with an attitude and all kinds of push back.

review_title: If you are a medical technologist seriously avoid!
pros:
I worked at the Atlanta main campus 

Has open door policy but many feel it is a facade

Benifits their are a few options dental is good medical has high deductible only decent price if you see their doctors only which I refused  due to the location of my job (the laboratory) and concern of privacy 

Other plans are high deductible 3000 and up but only has FSA no HSA which you only get to keep 500 of your fsa at the end of the year I prefer HSA only

The experience you gain far as demographics and testing depending on your department is something good to gain and you can always keep with you forever

Has whole life insurance plan but when researching the company I was skeptical of the reputation
cons:
Communication with floor and laboratory is very poor this is a transplant hospital communication with Lab and important hospital units very poor have to. Stay on nurses about testing to prepare for surgeries 

No advancement lower level supervisors shift supervisors department supervisors keep information for learning new material away from certain techs only allow favorites to do such or know such far as conferences new info about LIS systems new procedures many tasks do not have policies at all have to go by word of mouth which is not proper especially when tasks are performed and the way it's suposed to be done changes and appears you did it wrong  which many complain about 

**you must maintain a paper trail **

Training is a huge issue training should be precise for everyone regardless of ethnic or racial differences no one should be signed off and rushed to their shifts not being shown. All procedures of tests and with policies being either outdated or non existent it makes it harder for techs
 
Hospital has around 480 beds over 500 patients includes testing for outpatient clinics, infusion center, spinal clinic and the other locations of piedmont will send their tests to this location  on all three shifts 

Second shift is probably the most busy shift nights shift you WILL more than likely work by your self Lot of times short staff 

EXTREMELY HIGH TURNOVER lost 10 people within two months I was warned of this during my interview which I kept to my self but I was told most techs get there experience and do not stay more than two years due to no advancement over worked short staffed and poor raises I took the advice and did just that


And last but not least the notion that this is the highest paying hospital system for all  bonuses differentials base pay is FALSE hospitals have paid attention to what is being said about piedmont and offer higher pay and more alternative scheduling something piedmont hasnt adopted as of yet
